summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs news briefing from October 23, 2020, covering a wide range of national security, criminal, and political news. Key topics include warnings about Russian and Iranian election interference, updates on various criminal investigations, and political developments including the Supreme Court nomination of Amy Coney Barrett. The document serves as a daily intelligence summary for FBI leadership.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Warned about foreign election interference and emphasized the FBI's commitment to protecting election integrity. Mentioned in context of Iranian and Russian interference activities.

persons.name: John Ratcliffe
persons.context: Announced that Iran and Russia obtained voter registration information and that Iran sent spoofed emails to intimidate voters. Faced criticism from Democratic lawmakers.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in multiple contexts including election interference, considering firing FBI Director Wray, Supreme Court nominations, and stimulus negotiations.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned in context of election interference, Hunter Biden email controversy, and his plans for Supreme Court reform if elected.

persons.name: Hunter Biden
persons.context: Central figure in email controversy involving alleged business dealings with foreign entities, mentioned in context of FBI investigation pressure.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: Commented on election interference, stating Iran is not on par with Russia. Also involved in stimulus negotiations.

persons.name: Mark Warner
persons.context: Warned foreign adversaries not to interfere in elections and commented on Ratcliffe's statements about Iranian interference.

persons.name: Marco Rubio
persons.context: Jointly warned with Mark Warner against foreign election interference and urged public skepticism of sensational claims.

persons.name: Amy Coney Barrett
persons.context: Nomination advanced by Senate Judiciary Committee despite Democratic boycott. Expected to be confirmed before election.

persons.name: Lindsey Graham
persons.context: Advanced Barrett nomination and authorized subpoenas for Facebook and Twitter CEOs regarding content moderation.

persons.name: Tony Bobulinski
persons.role: Former Business Partner of Hunter Biden
persons.context: Came forward claiming Joe Biden was involved in business deals and was set to receive a cut from China deals.

persons.name: Alexander Hillel Treisman
persons.context: Arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives, allegedly planning to assassinate Joe Biden.

persons.name: Derek Chauvin
persons.context: Charged in George Floyd case; third-degree murder charge dismissed but other charges upheld.

persons.name: George Floyd
persons.context: Mentioned in context of criminal case against police officers involved in his death.

persons.name: Steven Mnuchin
persons.context: Involved in stimulus negotiations with Nancy Pelosi.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Mentioned in context of Trump considering firing current FBI Director Wray, similar to Comey's firing.

persons.name: Preet Bharara
persons.context: Sued by professional gambler Billy Walters alleging misconduct in insider trading case.

persons.name: Billy Walters
persons.context: Sued Preet Bharara and DOJ alleging misconduct in his insider trading conviction case.

persons.name: Edward Mangano
persons.context: Convicted on corruption charges; defense seeking to overturn conviction based on alleged perjury by witness.

persons.name: Harendra Singh
persons.context: Key government witness in Mangano corruption case accused of perjury in separate civil case.

persons.name: Paul Manafort
persons.context: New York court upheld dismissal of state mortgage fraud charges on double jeopardy grounds.

connections.description: Trump reportedly considering firing Wray after the election, with sources saying Trump regards Wray as having separated himself from the president.
Trump and Ratcliffe reportedly seeking declassification of Russia inquiry document, with Ratcliffe facing pressure from Trump to deliver intelligence.
Hunter Biden's business dealings and email controversy involving alleged foreign business deals that reportedly included Joe Biden.
Former business partners; Bobulinski came forward claiming Joe Biden was involved in their business deals.
Jointly issued bipartisan warning against foreign election interference as leaders of Senate Intelligence Committee.
Engaged in stimulus package negotiations, with Pelosi saying they were 'just about there' on a deal.
As Judiciary Committee Chairman, Graham advanced Barrett's nomination despite Democratic boycott.
Singh was key government witness in Mangano corruption case; defense alleges Singh committed perjury.
Bharara prosecuted Walters for insider trading; Walters now suing Bharara alleging misconduct in the case.

events.title: Election Interference Warning
events.description: FBI Director Wray and DNI Ratcliffe warned that Russia and Iran obtained voter registration information and that Iran sent spoofed emails to intimidate voters.

events.title: Barrett Nomination Advanced
events.description: Senate Judiciary Committee advanced Amy Coney Barrett's Supreme Court nomination 12-0 despite Democratic boycott.

events.title: Chauvin Charge Dismissed
events.description: Minnesota judge dismissed third-degree murder charge against Derek Chauvin in George Floyd case but upheld other charges.

events.title: Goldman Sachs 1MDB Settlement
events.description: Goldman Sachs admitted to breaking corruption laws and agreed to pay nearly $3 billion to settle 1MDB probe.

events.title: Remdesivir FDA Approval
events.description: FDA officially approved remdesivir as first COVID-19 treatment drug, having previously authorized it only for emergency use.

events.title: Biden Business Allegations
events.description: Former Hunter Biden business partner Tony Bobulinski came forward claiming Joe Biden was involved in business deals and set to receive cut from China deals.

events.title: Assassination Plot Arrest
events.description: Alexander Hillel Treisman arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives, allegedly planning to assassinate Joe Biden.

keyFacts: U.S. intelligence officials warned that Russia and Iran obtained voter registration information and that Iran sent spoofed emails designed to intimidate voters ahead of the 2020 election.
Former Hunter Biden business partner Tony Bobulinski claimed Joe Biden was involved in business deals and was set to receive a cut from China deals, contradicting Biden campaign denials.
Alexander Hillel Treisman was arrested in North Carolina with guns and explosives, allegedly planning to assassinate Joe Biden according to federal court documents.
Senate Judiciary Committee advanced Amy Coney Barrett's Supreme Court nomination 12-0 despite Democratic boycott, with full Senate vote scheduled for October 26.
Goldman Sachs admitted to breaking corruption laws and agreed to pay nearly $3 billion to settle investigations into its dealings with the Malaysian investment fund 1MDB.
